metadata.case_name: Messrs. Swadesamitran Ltd., Madras v. their workmen

facts.text: On August 26, 1950, the respondents addressed a charter of demands to the appellant containing eleven demands, intimating that if not granted, they would go on strike.
Appellant informed respondents it was working at a loss, retrenchment and rationalisation under consideration, promised sympathetic consideration when financial condition improved; demands withdrawn.
On January 24, 1951, respondents addressed communication with thirteen demands coupled with strike threat; copy sent to State Government requesting reference to tribunal.
Conciliation Officer found demands not justified, reported on February 22, 1951.
Respondents repeated request for reference; Government ordered on April 24, 1951, no case for reference.
Appellant effecting retrenchment due to steep rise in newsprint prices, scarcity of supplies, Government of India price-page schedule, progressive mechanisation by installing linotype machines.
Respondents' Union called strike ballot; decided to strike, notice issued on May 9, 1951.
Appellant appealed not to precipitate, promised consideration of demands, warned strike notice refusal to work would deem resignation.
Conciliation Officer advised respondents not to strike.
Respondents went on strike on May 30, 1951.
Before strike, services of 39 workmen terminated by notice as retrenchment effective May 18, 1951.
Respondents filed writ petition in Madras High Court for reference under s.10(1)(c); allowed, but appeal modified to direction under s.12(5).
Strike called off June 12, 1951; offered to resume work, but appellant engaged new hands, re-engaged only some.
On November 3, 1951, three items including justification of retrenchment of 39 workmen referred to Industrial Tribunal Madras under s.10(1)(c).

Industrial Tribunal held strike unjustified, retrenchment justified though last come first go not strictly followed, preference to mechanically inclined with good eyesight; no unfair practice; no relief.
Labour Appellate Tribunal found findings on bona fides and validity not justified; remanded for four points including compliance with last come first go and unfair practice/victimisation.
Post-remand, Industrial Tribunal: necessity and extent justified, no mala fides; but last come first go not observed for 15 out of 39; ordered reinstatement of 15 without back wages; no order for 24.

Labour Appellate Tribunal: confirmed retrenchment of 39 justified but last come first go not followed, no justification to depart; reinstated 15 with half back wages; 24 compensation half month's wages per year of service.

legal_issues.text: Whether Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in directing reinstatement despite finding retrenchment necessary and bona fide, and strike unjustified.
Whether Labour Appellate Tribunal exceeded jurisdiction by inquiring into validity and reasonableness of selection for retrenchment.
Whether principle of 'last come first go' was complied with in retrenchment, and if departed, whether justified.
Whether reinstatement appropriate relief or only compensation; quantum of compensation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal erred in directing reinstatement inconsistent with findings of bona fides, necessity of retrenchment, and unjustified strike; interference only if mala fide.
Retrenchment is normal management function; once necessity made out, discretion in selection absolute; tribunal exceeded jurisdiction by scrutinising selection.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: J.K. Iron Steel Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen (Civil Appeal No. 266 of 1958)

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if retrenchment of 15 unjustified, reinstatement not proper; compensation instead; compensation to 24 unjustified.

respondent_arguments.text: Retrenchment of 39 workmen violated 'last come first go' principle without justification; amounted to unfair labour practice or victimisation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial rule of last come first go; s.25G Industrial Disputes Act

court_reasoning.text: Two aspects: (1) necessity for retrenchment of 39 justified (unjustified strike, financial reasons); bona fides established. (2) Selection must follow 'last come first go' unless valid reasons with evidence; departure for 15 not justified.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bona fides in necessity irrelevant to fairness in selection; no inconsistency in findings.

court_reasoning.text: Management prerogative to retrench if justified, but must ordinarily follow 'last come first go'; departure allowed for efficiency, reliability etc., with reliable evidence; onus on employer to justify.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Departure without justification can itself indicate mala fides or unfair practice.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's evidence (testimony of Mr. Lakshminarasimhan, statements T-1, T-2) from memory, no contemporaneous records; defects attributed not satisfactory; personal knowledge doubted; specific cases demonstrably unsatisfactory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal correctly rejected evidence; retrenchment of 15 unfair labour practice.

court_reasoning.text: Improper retrenchment entitles to reinstatement; new hands or delay no bar; compensation quantum discretionary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Consistent with precedents on wrongful dismissal/discharge.

holdings.text: Industrial tribunals have jurisdiction to examine compliance with 'last come first go' and justification for departure; onus on employer.
Departure from 'last come first go' without sound reasons amounts to unfair labour practice; reinstatement and compensation upheld.
Reinstatement proper for improper retrenchment despite new hands or delay.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Navigation Industrials, Alleppey And Certain Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Accepted and applied principle of last come first go in retrenchment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cuttack Electric Supply Co. Ltd. And Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Accepted and applied principle of last come first go in retrenchment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shaparia Dock and Steel Company And Their Workers
precedents_cited.relevance: Accepted and applied principle of last come first go in retrenchment.

precedents_cited.case_name: J.K. Iron Steel Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.citation: Civil Appeal No. 266 of 1958 decided on 11-2-1960
precedents_cited.relevance: Departure from last come first go without sound reasoning not bona fide; does not support absolute management discretion.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. The All-India Punjab National Bank Employees Federation
precedents_cited.relevance: Reinstatement not defeated by lapse of time or fresh hands in wrongful dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: National Transport and General Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen
precedents_cited.citation: Civil Appeal No. 312 of 1956 decided on January 22, 1957
precedents_cited.relevance: Reinstatement not defeated by lapse of time or fresh hands in wrongful dismissal/discharge/retrenchment.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference for adjudication; government duties; statutory recognition of 'last come first go' with reasons for departure.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; upheld Labour Appellate Tribunal's order reinstating 15 workmen with half back wages and awarding compensation to remaining 24 retrenched workmen at half month's wages per year of service.
outcome.relief_granted: Reinstatement of 15 workmen with half back wages; compensation to 24 workmen.

key_quotes.text: "the ordinary industrial rule of retrenchment is last come first go, and where other things are equal this rule has to be followed by the employer in effecting retrenchment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on retrenchment principle and exceptions.

key_quotes.text: "departure from the ordinary industrial rule of retrenchment without any justification may itself, in a proper case, lead to the inference that the impugned retrenchment is the result of ulterior considerations."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies tribunal interference and finding of unfair practice.

key_quotes.text: "Ordinarily, if a workman has been improperly and illegally retrenched he is entitled to claim reinstatement."
key_quotes.speaker: court
